awd_titl_txt: Lasers and Fiber Optics Regional Center
awd_abstract_narration:
Lasers and fiber optics (LFO) undergird most twenty-first century advanced technologies. They are fueling innovations in medical instrumentation, photonics integrated circuits, telecommunications technologies, laser additive manufacturing, remote sensing, analytical instrumentation, and other industries. The economic impact of light-based technologies on the U.S. gross domestic product was $7.5 trillion in 2010. The Department of Labor projects that 1,710 LFO technicians will be needed annually between 2014 and 2024. U.S. colleges with LFO and photonics programs produce only 300 technicians annually. The demand is almost six times the supply. This project will support the education of the workforce needed to keep the U.S. as the world leader in laser and fiber optics enabled technologies.

The ATE Regional Center, LASER-TEC, proposes to continue developing the LFO workforce for the southeastern U.S., and will expand the current network of 21 partner colleges. The industrial corporate network will increase to include companies from different sectors of the economy. The goals are to: 1) Increase and strengthen LFO academic programs to meet industry demand; 2) Create and offer LFO professional development programs for secondary school teachers, college faculty, and incumbent workers; 3) Develop LFO curriculum materials for secondary schools, colleges, and industry; 4) Develop, promote, and deliver outreach and awareness programs to secondary STEM teachers, advisors, counselors, and administrators; 5) Develop strategies and materials to recruit and retain underrepresented groups to promote diversity in LFO programs; and 6) Identify and disseminate LFO technicians' skillsets and employment needs in the southeastern U.S. LASER-TEC is working with AIM Photonics, Power America, Advanced Functional Fabrics of America, and other Manufacturing USA Institutes to provide the workforce education and training as new technologies are developed.

por.por_cntn:
Background

The Center for Laser and Fiber Optics Education (LASER-TEC), funded by NSF ATE DUE-1700352, was established with the mission of expanding and boosting technical education in photonics to meet the growing workforce demand. LASER-TEC focused on improving the quality and sustainability of photonics college programs by mapping regional workforce demands, increasing faculty technical expertise, refining training facilities, and raising public awareness about academic and career opportunities in photonics technologies.

Photonics College Network

LASER-TEC convened a network of 44 two-year colleges, 30 of which actively offered photonics programs. This network includes 13 colleges with associate degree programs, 8 offering certificates and specializations, and 9 delivering individual photonics courses developed through the network. Together, these colleges form a comprehensive educational framework catering to diverse academic and career pathways in lasers, optics, photonics, and fiber optics technologies.

College Photonics Curricula

To support photonics education, LASER-TEC developed and distributed associate-level curriculum materials covering a wide range of topics, including photonics, fiber optics, spectroscopy, high-power lasers, solar thermal and photovoltaic technologies, biomedical applications, and wide-bandgap semiconductor technology. These resources, which include full courses, chapters, modules, guides, and outreach projects, are available under the Creative Commons License on the LASER-TEC website, ensuring accessibility to educators nationwide. To support the hands-on photonics exploration in schools and colleges, the Center developed, assembled, and distributed 1,211 optics kits.

Professional Development for College Faculty

Recognizing the importance of faculty expertise, LASER-TEC developed and delivered a variety of professional development programs. Highlights include five photonics courses offered in online and hybrid formats. Over the span of this award, 70 faculty members from 15 colleges attended LASER-TEC’s professional development courses, enhancing their ability to integrate photonics technology into their teaching.

College Student Support Initiatives

To support student retention and career placement, LASER-TEC facilitated engagement with the photonics industry. Through partnerships with professional societies, the Center sponsored student participation in national and regional conferences, providing exposure to industry trends, networking opportunities, and career pathways. Students visited leading research institutions and companies such as the National Ignition Facility at Lawrence Livermore National Labs, the University of Central Florida College of Photonics, UNCC Photonics Research Center in North Carolina, L3Harris, and Synoptics.

The Center organized interview sessions with 24 photonics companies and two national laboratories, helping students transition from education to employment. It is estimated that over 1,000 photonics graduates are now employed in critical industries, including advanced manufacturing, semiconductors, telecommunications, biomedical, healthcare, security, and defense.

K-12 Student Pipeline

LASER-TEC actively engaged the K-12 pipeline through targeted outreach and professional development programs. A notable initiative was the two-day “Lasers and Fiber Optics” hands-on workshop, designed to enhance teachers’ expertise and introduce them to academic and career opportunities in photonics. During this award period, 254 teachers participated in workshops, collectively impacting 22,929 students with knowledge of photonics technologies.

For students, LASER-TEC organized interactive bootcamps to explore photonics and related fields such as electronics, automation, and programming. Five standalone photonics camps were developed, hosting 46 sessions and engaging 614 students. Additional outreach efforts included field trips, classroom presentations, open houses, career fairs, and networking events, resulting in 91 events and 6,980 participants.

Industry Collaboration

The growth of the skilled photonics workforce was supported by LASER-TEC’s Industry Network . The network, comprising 162 companies and seven organizations, engaged actively with groups such as the Florida Photonics Cluster, North Carolina Research Triangle, and professional organizations including LIA, SPIE, OSA, IEEE, and Manufacturing USA’s Power America. These collaborations ensured alignment between academic programs and industry needs.

Incumbent Photonics Workforce

Upskilling the incumbent workforce was a critical focus for LASER-TEC. The Center offered a variety of professional development opportunities for photonics technicians and laser safety officers. A significant milestone was the agreement with the Laser Institute of America, which recognized LASER-TEC courses as eligible for continued education credits. This initiative boosted workforce readiness and maintained high standards in the photonics industry.

Women in Photonics

LASER-TEC took steps to improve the recruitment and retention of women in photonics. The “Tech Like a Girl” program, developed in partnership with AAUW, incorporated best practices to raise awareness about STEM careers and close the gender gap. The Center also established the Women in Photonics Technologies Network, creating a platform for sharing experiences and fostering a supportive community. These efforts promoted diversity and inclusion within the photonics workforce.

COVID-19 Response

The COVID-19 pandemic posed unique challenges to photonics education, particularly in maintaining hands-on learning experiences. In response, LASER-TEC assembled and shipped Light and Optics Experiment Kits directly to faculty and students at home. These kits sustained entry-level photonics courses at 11 LASER-TEC colleges and ensured continuity of education during the nationwide shift to distance learning.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/13/2024
Modified by: Natalia Chekhovskaya
